row.1: You seize the orb. It's warm, vibrating. You break it, convinced you’ve found the key to your normality. The syringe is there. You inject the silvery liquid. You wait. You breathe heavily. Harder. You want to feel something. You want… to change.

But nothing. No loss of sense. No transformation. Just... your breath. Getting shorter. You glance at the oxygen gauge. It's dropping. You panic. You want to run. You want to start over. But it's too late. And there, in an old half-burnt notebook, a phrase written in black ink:
"It wasn't your body that needed to change. It was your world."

The oxygen runs out. Everything blurs. You fall to your knees. And at that precise moment, everything changes. The room lights up. The air returns. But you did nothing. You understand: oxygen was never a resource. It was the invisible privilege.
row.2: That of a world designed for you. A world that always let you breathe while others suffocated in silence. And today, for the first time… you ran out of air.

row.1: Accessibility is not a bonus. It's digital oxygen. Invisible. Essential. Vital. Exclusion doesn't wear a uniform. It's soft. Polite. Coded. Automatic. It hides in 'This isn’t made for you', 'You just have to adapt.' And in every silence where eyes look away.
row.2: You weren’t hunted. You were a witness. And now... the real game begins.
row.3: And this time… you can’t pretend you don’t know.

row.1: You thought you were looking for an escape. But what you found... is the truth.
row.2: In this world, exclusion doesn't wear a uniform. It's soft, polite, coded, automatic.
row.3: It’s in 'this wasn’t made for you', in 'you just have to adapt', in every minute of silence where people look away.
row.4: You weren’t the hero. You were the witness.
row.5: Now, the real game begins. And this time, you can’t pretend you don’t know.

row.3: If you are interested in the technique, you will find below some tips to apply to improve any issues encountered during the game:

1.problem: The link button has no distinctive style. This issue affects those who use a mouse. Keyboard navigators are not affected. Depending on usage, one can be disadvantaged if both navigation modes are not addressed.
1.advice: Do not overload styles if you are not familiar with their impacts.

1.title: Color Blindness
1.problem: The buttons were all the same color initially. By altering the contrast and brightness, the true colors are revealed. Color blindness is a visual impairment that affects color perception.
1.advice: Color choice is important in an application. Use high contrasts and do not convey information solely through color. Test your application with color blindness simulators.

1.title: Blindness
1.problem: The screen was broken, so we couldn't use our eyes. Blind individuals cannot access information presented solely in visual form, such as images, charts, or videos without alternative descriptions. Without a well-thought-out navigation structure, blind users may have difficulty navigating a website or application. Poorly designed forms can be difficult to understand and complete for those using screen readers. Blind users may get lost if interactive elements (buttons, links) are not clearly identified and described.

1.above: Use a solution that verifies accessible data, such as:
1.label: UUV

1.advice: Use alternative descriptions for images and other information-bearing elements. Follow ARIA (Accessible Rich Internet Applications) standards. Structure pages with titles and headers to facilitate navigation. Design accessible forms. Provide text alternatives for multimedia content. Test with screen readers.

1.title: Visual Disorder
1.problem: Labels were either too small or too large, input fields were far from their labels, and the page was too large.
1.advice: Enlarge interactive elements and reorganize them to simplify navigation. Use generous margins and white spaces to reduce visual clutter and improve overall readability.

1.title: Dyslexia
1.problem: Characters change without interruption. This visual-attention disorder disrupts the analysis of words and texts due to attention deficit. It can stem from inappropriate fonts, overly dense and unstructured text, lack of visual clarity (poor contrast or background, or cluttered layout), and complex navigation (non-intuitive or poorly organized menus or links).
1.advice: Make letters more distinct and easier to recognize by choosing a sans-serif font like Arial or Verdana. Use short, well-spaced paragraphs with generous line spacing. Ensure good contrast between text and background. Light backgrounds with dark text are often the most readable. Use headings, subheadings, bullet points, and numbers to organize content. Prefer left-aligned text rather than full justification, which can create irregular spacing that's hard to follow. Create a clear and intuitive navigation structure, with simple menus and well-labeled links.

1.title: Dyslexia
1.problem: Images disrupted our reading. Animated, flashing, or constantly moving elements can distract and make it difficult to focus on the main content.
1.advice: Limit animations, flashing images, and other distractions that can hinder concentration and reading.

1.title: Tremor
1.problem: The action surface represented by the red cross is very small. Motor impairments cause difficulties when interface elements are too small or close together, when user journeys require precise or rapid movements, or when interfaces are incompatible with devices like alternative keyboards or specialized mice.

1.above: Ensure all features are accessible via the keyboard and that the tab order is logical, as with:
1.label: UUV - Keyboard Navigation

1.advice: Ensure that buttons, links, and form fields are large enough and spaced out for easy access. Reduce the number of movements needed to complete a task and avoid complex actions like drag-and-drop.

1.title: Tremor
1.problem: The room was refrigerated, causing tremors. We had difficulty targeting keys and often pressed adjacent keys. Keyboard shortcuts also didn't work.
1.advice: Recommend using specialized keyboards with larger and more spaced keys or on-screen keyboards with customization options. Also, integrate dictation and voice input options to allow users to enter text without using the keyboard.

1.title: Deafness
1.problem: The sound volume is extremely low. Ambient music can also disturb concentration.
1.advice: Provide subtitles, text transcripts, and visual communication options such as sign language.
